poem:
Jewel Heist at the Louvre  

Two men in the night—  
Paris asleep,  
under the shadowed  
arches, they slip  
like whispers,  
beyond the gaze  
of Mona Lisa's  
guardians.  
Glint of ambition  
measured in millions,  
now wrapped in  
handcuffs, clinking  
like illicit jewels,  
their shine dulled  
by morning's relentless   
truth.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Two men arrested after Louvre jewel heist Two suspects have been arrested in relation to last Sunday’s heist at the Louvre museum in Paris, in which a gang of four men made off with crown jewels worth an estimated €88m (£76m), French media have reported. The Paris public prosecutor confirmed on Sunday that one man had been detained by organised crime squad officers at about 10pm (8pm UK time) on Saturday at Charles de Gaulle". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Two men arrested after Louvre jewel heist Two suspects have been arrested in relation to last Sunday’s heist at the Louvre museum in Paris, in which a gang of four men made off with crown jewels worth an estimated €88m (£76m), French media have reported. The Paris public prosecutor confirmed on Sunday that one man had been detained by organised crime squad officers at about 10pm (8pm UK time) on Saturday at Charles de Gaulle
